crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects suspicious UTF16 and Base64 encoded PowerShell code that starts with a $ sign and a single char variable
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature fires on the presence of Base64 encoded URI prefixes (http:// and https://) across any file. The simple presence of such strings is not inherently an indicator of malicious content, but is worth further investigation.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Registering wscript to autostart run key for dropped js/vbs

match_context.values: @{Details=wscript.exe "C:\ProgramData\onedrives.vbs"; EventID=13; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventType=SetValue; TargetObject=HKU\S-1-5-21-1070296143-2877979003-364783958-1001\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce\FnSokkSnlA}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects PowerShell command line contents that include a suspicious abnormal casing in the Net.Webclient (e.g. nEt.WEbCliEnT) string as used in obfuscation techniques

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Unsigned DLL Loaded by Windows Utility
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects windows utilities loading an unsigned or untrusted DLL.
Adversaries often abuse those programs to proxy execution of malicious code.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Registry Tampering by Potentially Suspicious Processes
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects suspicious registry modifications made by suspicious processes such as script engine processes such as WScript, or CScript etc.
These processes are rarely used for legitimate registry modifications, and their activity may indicate an attempt to modify the registry
without using standard tools like regedit.exe or reg.exe, potentially for evasion and persistence.

match_context.values: @{EventType=SetValue; EventID=13; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe; Details=DWORD (0x00000001); TargetObject=HKU\S-1-5-21-1070296143-2877979003-364783958-1001\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ZoneMap\ProxyBypass}

@{EventType=SetValue; EventID=13; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe; Details=DWORD (0x00000001); TargetObject=HKU\S-1-5-21-1070296143-2877979003-364783958-1001\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ZoneMap\IntranetName}

@{EventType=SetValue; EventID=13; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe; Details=DWORD (0x00000001); TargetObject=HKU\S-1-5-21-1070296143-2877979003-364783958-1001\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ZoneMap\UNCAsIntranet}

@{EventType=SetValue; Details=DWORD (0x00000000); Image=C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe; EventID=13; TargetObject=HKU\S-1-5-21-1070296143-2877979003-364783958-1001\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ZoneMap\AutoDetect}

@{Details=QWORD (0x00000000-0x0063cbf9); EventType=SetValue; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe; EventID=13; TargetObject=HKU\S-1-5-21-1070296143-2877979003-364783958-1001\Software\Microsoft\Windows Script\Settings\Telemetry\wscript.exe\VBScriptSetScriptStateStarted}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: RegAsm.EXE Execution Without CommandLine Flags or Files
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects the execution of "RegAsm.exe" without a commandline flag or file, which might indicate potential process injection activity.
Usually "RegAsm.exe" should point to a dedicated DLL file or call the help with the "/?" flag.

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=56953994707668803A070FBEA09B56ECA9C397AC,MD5=6E964AEBBF00FE8E25BF28CE22734E44,SHA256=613B37387DAF3698DF4A8BAF6E4350473EBC3F23682D368221CD8DEA9DE2FB63,IMPHASH=F34D5F2D4577ED6D9CEEC516C1F5A744; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=RegAsm.exe; Product=Microsoft\xae .NET Framework; Description=Microsoft .NET Assembly Registration Utility; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" "$ddsdgo =' [TRUNCATED]; CommandLine="C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319\RegAsm.exe"; FileVersion=4.8.9032.0 built by: NET481REL1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; IntegrityLevel=Medium; Image=C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319\RegAsm.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects non-interactive PowerShell activity by looking at the "powershell" process with a non-user GUI process such as "explorer.exe" as a parent.

match_context.values: @{CommandLine=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" "$ddsdgo =' [TRUNCATED]; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
When C# is compiled dynamically, a .cmdline file will be created as a part of the process.
Certain processes are not typically observed compiling C# code, but can do so without touching disk.
This can be used to unpack a payload for execution

match_context.values: @{TargetFilename=C:\Users\user\AppData\Local\Temp\0dvg1c10.cmdline}
@{Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\l24becp1.cmdline; EventID=11}

attributes.magic: ASCII text, with CRLF line terminators

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The VBScript code performs initial mathematical operations as filler. It then checks the computer name for specific substrings ("MAA1", "CAV", "LNP2", "-PC"), exiting if any are found, which is an anti-analysis technique. The script constructs a complex PowerShell command string in memory. This PowerShell command string is then executed in a hidden window using `WScript.Shell`.

The executed PowerShell script performs the following actions:
1.  Sets the TLS 1.2 security protocol.
2.  Defines a PowerShell variable `$ddsdgo` which holds a Base64 encoded payload.
3.  Uses `Add-Type` to define a custom `.NET` assembly loading mechanism from another embedded Base64 string.
4.  Defines a function `d` that downloads data from a randomly selected URL from a hardcoded list of two remote URLs.
5.  Defines a function `i` that reflectively loads a `.NET` assembly from a Base64 string and invokes a specified method within it.
6.  Attempts to download a second payload from one of the two following URLs:
    *   `https://au72nuxzv2.ufs.sh/f/4LhV5B1sDCwIRk19j8GEwu0JnXSMqWiCY2B5rOp7IogvHf4`
    *   `https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/remasd-6c702.firebasestorage.app/o/image.jpg?alt=media&token=20564d8b-9f51-4fc0-8439-3cca14ea7fc4`
7.  If a download is successful, it attempts to extract a Base64 encoded string from the downloaded content (expected between `<BASE64_START>` and `</BASE64_END>` tags).
8.  This extracted Base64 string is then reflectively loaded and executed as a `.NET` assembly using the `i` function.
9.  Finally, the script decodes the initial Base64 payload stored in the PowerShell variable `$ddsdgo` (after a string replacement operation) and executes it using `Invoke-Expression`.
